Rate Netting Procedures for LB&I Cases 4.10.26 page
) Purpose: This section provides guidance to ﬁeld examiners who receive (

) formal or informal requests for Net Rate Netting (NRN). NRN requests will Program Scope and be subject to formal claims procedures during examination consideration. Objectives purpose of this guidance is to ensure that LB&I ﬁeld examiners properly cases with NRN requests so that case processing functions in SB/SE or Appeals can properly compute interest after the case is closed. These dures do not apply to NRN requests worked in case processing units. (
) Audience: LB&I examiners (
) Policy Owner: Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration (
) Program Owner: LB&I Policy Office (
) Primary Stakeholders: Stakeholders include Centralized Case (CCP) and Office of Servicewide Interest.
) IRC
(d) was enacted by RRA ’
and provides for the equalization/ (

) elimination of the interest rate differential between overpayments and Background underpayments of two or more tax modules for the “same” taxpayer overlapping periods. The effect of the rate equalization results in the rate differential being netted to “zero”. The IRS calls this procedure “net netting”. See IRM
, Net Rate Interest Netting, for more

) Field examiners are more likely to encounter NRN requests in cases with (
) complex returns than in cases with less complex returns. Discussing Net Rate (

) In such cases, the ﬁeld examiner will determine if it is beneﬁcial to Netting with Taxpayers NRN with the taxpayer during the planning stage of the examination. If so, such discussions should clarify the following points: a. NRN is performed after offsetting. b. NRN is frequently confused with offsetting. See IRM

for information. c. Offsetting can occur when there is an outstanding overpayment and derpayment for which interest is allowed or charged over the same of time between two or more tax modules. Example: An overpayment of tax exists in one year and an ment of tax exists in another year. Offsets can occur tax years of the “same” or different taxpayers. d. NRN can occur when there is an overpayment(s) and where interest will be/has been allowed or charged during the same period. Interest being allowed or charged during the same time referred to as an “overlapping period”. The overlapping periods for Cat. No.
J (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Field examiners are more likely to encounter NRN requests in cases with complex returns than in cases with less complex returns.
NRN is performed after offsetting. NRN is frequently confused with offsetting. See IRM

for more information. Offsetting can occur when there is an outstanding overpayment and un- derpayment for which interest is allowed or charged over the same period of time between two or more tax modules.

NRN can occur when there is an overpayment(s) and underpayment(s) where interest will be/has been allowed or charged during the same time period. Interest being allowed or charged during the same time period, is referred to as an “overlapping period”. The overlapping periods for over-
payment(s) and underpayment(s) can be for different tax years and different tax modules including employment tax, income tax, etc., for the “same” taxpayer.
Example: An overpayment of income tax for
was refunded to taxpayer on October
resulting in a module balance zero. In
, an examination of tax year
resulted in additional tax owed by the “same” taxpayer. There was an overlapping period of overpayment interest for
and derpayment interest for
from the due date of the
return until the October

refund date. Offsetting can be performed systematically by Master File or manually the campus after a case closes. Offsets between different taxpayers be done manually. Note: Both NRN and offsetting require special case processing instruc- tions on Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Processing. See IRM
for speciﬁc instructions.
Example: An overpayment of income tax for
was refunded to the taxpayer on October
resulting in a module balance of zero. In
, an examination of tax year
resulted in additional tax owed by the “same” taxpayer. There was an overlapping period of overpayment interest for
and un- derpayment interest for
from the due date of the
return until the October
refund date.
The IRS will process any resolved tax period(s) in the NRN request and the information for any unresolved tax period(s) will be retained.
a. A resolved tax period is where the overlapping underpayment and over

payment periods have been identiﬁed and the amounts have been determined and are no longer subject to controversy in Exam, Appeals, or in a court. b. An unresolved tax period is where the overlapping underpayment and overpayment periods and amounts have not been determined because they are in Exam, Appeals or the taxpayer is pursuing litigation.

or in a court. b. An unresolved tax period is where the overlapping underpayment and overpayment periods and amounts have not been determined they are in Exam, Appeals or the taxpayer is pursuing litigation. Note: The taxpayer may decide to remove any or all tax period(s) from the up until the point of time the request is processed. (

below. Taxpayers will ﬁnd instructions for requesting NRN in Rev. Proc.
(See Rev. Proc. for interest accruing before October

) The ﬁeld examiner will review the information provided by the taxpayer to determine whether the NRN information provided is accurate and sufficient process (perfected NRN request). The taxpayer should specify all underpayment and overpayment periods and attest whether any of the have been previously used for NRN purposes. Note: If any overlapping period was previously used for NRN, the taxpayer attach the prior NRN interest computation to the current NRN request. will assist campus personnel in processing the NRN request. , taxpayers who have fully paid the related interest amounts may ﬁle a claim for refund and receive judicial review by a United States District Court or Court of Federal Claims, if the accounts involved ﬁrst paid in full. Flora v. United States,
U.S.

) If a taxpayer requests a “net” balance during an examination, it may be a request for either “offsetting” or “net rate netting”. NRN is not the same as Distinguished setting between tax years. Rate Netting (

) NRN equalizes/eliminates the interest rate differential between and underpayments of two or more tax modules for the “same” taxpayer overlapping periods so that the interest rate differential is netted to zero. IRM

, Net Rate Interest Netting, for more information. The must provide a written request for NRN. Use NRN in the following the taxpayer’s request: a. An examination underpayment that overlaps with previously refunded overpayment(s) on different year(s) or different tax module(s). b. An examination overpayment that overlaps with previously paid tax sessment(s) on different year(s) or different tax module(s). (

) Offsetting is transferring credit from an overpaid tax module to an underpaid tax module. The Service generally offsets unsettled modules through File programming, however, it can be done manually by processing An unsettled module is a module with either a credit (refund due taxpayer) debit (taxpayer owes) balance. See IRC
(a) and IRM
, Under- payment Interest on Liabilities Paid by Credit/Offset. (

) Offsetting is done before any NRN adjustments. The following are offsets that will be done before processing a NRN request: a. Overpayment(s) and underpayment(s) closing during the same time b. Overpayment(s) closing with an outstanding underpayment(s) on tax year(s). c. Underpayment(s) closing with a current overpayment(s) on a different year(s). (

taxpayer is making a claim for refund, the interest must ﬁrst be paid in full. See IRM 25.6.1.10.2.6, Claims for Credit or Refund – Form and Content.

NRN equalizes/eliminates the interest rate differential between overpayments and underpayments of two or more tax modules for the “same” taxpayer overlapping periods so that the interest rate differential is netted to zero. See IRM 20.2.14.6, Net Rate Interest Netting, for more information. The taxpayer must provide a written request for NRN. Use NRN in the following situations at the taxpayer’s request:

Overpayment(s) and underpayment(s) closing during the same time Overpayment(s) closing with an outstanding underpayment(s) on different tax year(s). Underpayment(s) closing with a current overpayment(s) on a different tax year(s).
Requests for NRN may be received by either the campus or the ﬁeld examiner.

4.10 Examination of Returns
a. Determine if the NRN request is entirely between different taxpayers. If so, mark through the date stamp on the request and initial it. b. Issue Letter
, Net Rate Netting Request Involving More than One TIN, to the taxpayer indicating the Service is unable to process the request. See IRM

for speciﬁc instructions. c. Determine if any tax period(s) for the taxpayer who submitted the are subject to netting. If so, indicate the periods on the letter, however, information related to other taxpayers may not be disclosed. Note: If the ﬁeld examiner determines that any portion of the request should be denied because the multiple TINs are not the “same” taxpayer, the has the right to elevate the issue to Appeals. (
) If there are other issues that require Appeals consideration, the ﬁeld should notate the NRN request on Form
, Report Transmittal, and the facts and law surrounding the NRN issue. Example
: Corporation A ﬁles a NRN request with multiple TINs. A has overpayments for periods
, and
and an underpayment for period Subsidiary B has underpayments for periods
, and
Subsidiary B joined the consolidated group at the beginning of period
Subsidiary B net its underpayment with the overpayment of parent A for period
, but the overpayments and underpayments of periods
and
can be netted.

Example 1: Corporation A ﬁles a NRN request with multiple TINs. Corporation A has overpayments for periods 1, 2, and 3 and an underpayment for period 4. Subsidiary B has underpayments for periods 1, 2, 3, and 4. Subsidiary B joined the consolidated group at the beginning of period 2. Subsidiary B cannot net its underpayment with the overpayment of parent A for period 1, but the overpayments and underpayments of periods 2 and 3 can be netted.
Example 2: Parent Corporation A ﬁles a NRN request for overlapping periods of underpayment and overpayment interest involving Corporation A and its sub-

of underpayment and overpayment interest involving Corporation A and its sidiaries B and C. These three entities have separate TINs. The IRS determines that Corporation A is not the same taxpayer as Corporations B and C for purposes of interest rate netting because Corporation A’s underpayment was incurred before Corporations B and C became members of a consolidated group with Corporation A as the parent. Therefore, Corporations B and C are not jointly liable with Corporation A for the income tax underpayment. However, the IRS determines that Corporation B can ﬁle a net rate request for its own underpayment of employment taxes and its own overpayment of excise taxes. Similarly, the IRS determines that Corporation C can ﬁle its own net rate request. The IRS will advise Parent Corporation A (the entity that ﬁled the net rate request) that its request will not be approved, but that Corporations B and C should ﬁle their own requests for their own overlapping periods.

of underpayment and overpayment interest involving Corporation A and its sidiaries B and C. These three entities have separate TINs. The IRS determines that Corporation A is not the same taxpayer as Corporations B C for purposes of interest rate netting because Corporation A’s was incurred before Corporations B and C became members of a group with Corporation A as the parent. Therefore, Corporations B and C not jointly liable with Corporation A for the income tax underpayment. the IRS determines that Corporation B can ﬁle a net rate request for its underpayment of employment taxes and its own overpayment of excise Similarly, the IRS determines that Corporation C can ﬁle its own net rate request. The IRS will advise Parent Corporation A (the entity that ﬁled the rate request) that its request will not be approved, but that Corporations B C should ﬁle their own requests for their own overlapping periods. to the taxpayer and enclose the original NRN request with the date stamp crossed out and initialed.

d. Inform the taxpayer that the resolved tax periods will be worked when case is closed and the unresolved tax periods will be retained until they are resolved. See IRM
for deﬁnitions of resolved and unre- solved tax periods. e. Determine if the case involves unagreed issues not related to the NRN request. If so, indicate on Form
, Report Transmittal, that there is NRN request to be processed, the date received, and where to ﬁnd the NRN request and related workpapers. (

Tax periods involved c. Underpayment amount(s) and date of payment, if paid d. Overpayment amount(s) and date of refund or offset e. Identiﬁcation of overlapping period(s) f. Certiﬁcation that the net rate has not been used during the identiﬁed lapping period(s) Note: Field examiners should be aware that a prior netting adjustment could been made during an overlapping period(s), but it may not have been pletely used – there may be a remaining amount of an overpayment or underpayment that can still be netted. However, the ﬁeld examiner should request that the taxpayer provide speciﬁc unused amounts, if available. (

to the taxpayer and maintain a copy in the case ﬁle. (
